title: SB 42
content: The people of California enact the following. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability is established as the statewide postsecondary education coordination and planning entity within the Governor's office, under the direct control of an executive director. The Governor appoints the Executive Director of the Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability, who has all duties and powers vested by law, including hiring staff and contracting services. The appointment is subject to Senate confirmation, and the salary is determined by the Government Code. An advisory board is established to review and make recommendations on the functions of the Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability. It consists of the Chairs of the Senate and Assembly education committees as ex officio members, along with six public members with postsecondary education experience appointed by the Senate and Assembly. The office must consult with the advisory board on its operations and recommendations. The advisory board, governed by the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act, meets quarterly to report on higher education in California and review the Executive Director's performance. Members serve without pay but receive expenses reimbursement. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability advises the Governor, Legislature, and other officials on postsecondary education. It consults with higher education segments and stakeholders, including faculty, students, K-12 representatives, and the business community. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability advises on state goals, reviews cross-segmental initiatives, and advises on new institutions/campuses. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability reviews proposals for new programs, coordinates with nearby educational institutions, and acts as a clearinghouse for postsecondary education information. It maintains a comprehensive database to ensure data comparability and supports longitudinal studies of individual students. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability maintains a database that supports educational research needs for all segments of higher education in California. It ensures data compatibility with various educational systems and provides internet access to data. The office also complies with student privacy laws when disclosing personally identifiable information. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability in California maintains a database for educational research purposes. Personally identifiable student information cannot be shared without authorization. Significant changes to student data require notification to legislative committees and the Governor. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability in California reviews proposals for changes in eligibility pools for admission to public institutions and postsecondary education. It conducts studies on the percentages of California public high school graduates eligible for admission to UC and CSU, submits reports to the Legislature, and manages data systems for information reported by higher education institutions. The Office of Higher Education Performance and Accountability in California can require public postsecondary education institutions to submit data on various aspects for effective planning and policy development. It reports to the Governor and Legislature on progress and objectives annually. The Legislative Analyst's Office will review its performance by January 1, 2020. This article will be in effect until January 1, 2021, and will be repealed unless a later statute extends the date. If the Commission on State Mandates finds that this act imposes state-mandated costs, reimbursement will be made to local agencies and school districts.
